userreviews.userReview: A tremendous idea for a book that, if handled by a skilled author, would have had the potential to be a fantastic read.Unfortunately, Wallace fails to captivate with his writing style, and perhaps worse, in a book providing "forensic evidence for the crucifixion" there is not one iota of physical evidence present.There are numerous suppositions as to what PROBABLY happened, sprinkled with generic scriptures from the crucifixion story.The author made no attempt to use historical evidence of the crucifixion (of which there is plenty) and instead jumps from idea to idea.I read the book to help myself learn more about the crucifixion and to be able to defend it's credibility with others, but instead I felt like I received a very watered down account of what I already knew. I left the book unsatisfied and disappointed.

I read this as part of my Easter reading. Overall worth checking out and when I get the chance gives me a taste of what to expect in Cold-Case Christianity (which until reading this book didn't have a ton of motivation to read). Looking at his arguments he gives some compelling evidence why many of the ideas Liberal scholars will take against the Resurrection are often found lacking when real world applications of how evidence is used in a crime scene investigation are used. If you compare this work to Ehrman (as an example, but as any Christian who has spent more than 10 seconds on the Internet knows, these arguments are everywhere) who often makes the claim that he's using the same logic one would use in a trial to make the case against the Resurrection one might find Ehrman's argument lacking (and not to go all fleshy/natural on this one, but who are you going to believe about solving a crime, a detective or an academic, wait don't answer that). That being said this little book is worth a look.

"Alive" is a short apologetic booklet that looks at the evidence surrounding Jesus' resurrection from the point of view of a cold case detective. What is the most reasonable explanation for the accounts found in secular, historical sources and in the Bible?The author explained his process and then examined the possible explanations using his experiences as a cold case detective. He did a good job of covering the various, possible scenarios surrounding the crucifixion and resurrection. His reasoning was easy to follow and logical. Overall, this would be a good resource for those who are uncertain about Jesus' resurrection and only have time for a quick read. It will especially appeal to those who are interested in detective work. However, this will be too brief for anyone wanting a thorough, deep look on the subject.

description: "If Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile; you are still in your sins" (1 Cor. 15:17).The resurrection. As far as doctrines go, it's a game changer. Many accept the resurrection without giving it much thought. But isn't something so important worthy of our wrestling with it? What if we approached the issue of the resurrection in an unbiased manner and assessed it as a cold case detective would evaluate a crime scene? Author J. Warner Wallace is a cold-case detective. He also used to be an atheist. Follow along in this brief presentation of his approach in applying his detective's expertise to the accounts of the resurrection. Wallace believes the case is nothing but compelling: Jesus is alive!
title: Alive: A Cold-Case Approach To The Resurrection
